title: Arrest Warrant From ICC Pierces Putin’s Aura of Impunity
description: A highly symbolic move by the International Criminal Court, which accused President Vladimir V. Putin of war crimes, carries moral weight.

title: China’s Xi to Visit Putin Under Shadow of War-Crimes Warrant
description: Global divisions over Russia’s actions in Ukraine widened as China said Xi Jinping would go to Russia to help make peace, in a move widely seen as a stark sign of support for President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: What to Know about the ICC’s Arrest Warrant for Putin
description: The International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for President Vladimir V. Putin and a Russian official for war crimes. Here’s a look at the warrant and what it could mean for Russia’s leader.

title: When Judges Decide on Abortion
description: Cases in Poland and Texas bring legal vulnerabilities into sharp relief.

title: Turkey’s Erdogan Finally Endorses Finland’s NATO Bid, but Not Sweden’s
description: With a difficult election coming in May, the Turkish president keeps insisting that Sweden is harboring alleged Kurdish terrorists and other dissidents.

title: For Iran, Saudi Détente Could Ease Strains Regionally and at Home
description: Long seen as a regional troublemaker and on the defensive from advances made by Israel, Iran sees the restoration of ties with its rival as a win for all sides, analysts say.

title: Turkey Moves to Ratify Finland’s NATO Membership
description: Finland joining the alliance after decades of military nonalignment would be a major shift and represents a significant diplomatic and strategic defeat for Russia.

title: The U.S. has long been wary of the I.C.C., but relations have been thawing.
description: Many democracies have joined the court, which investigates war crimes, genocide and crimes against humanity, but Washington has been concerned that the tribunal could someday try to prosecute Americans.

title: Simone Segouin, Teenage Fighter in French Resistance, Dies at 97
description: Portrayed in Life magazine in 1944 as a simple farm girl brandishing a submachine gun, she became a symbol of the partisans who helped defeat the Nazis.

title: Justice Dept. Investigating TikTok’s Owner Over Possible Spying on Journalists
description: The inquiry appears to be tied to an admission by the app’s owner, ByteDance, that employees had inappropriately obtained Americans’ data. The company said it had fired the workers involved.

title: Ukraine Jets: More MIG Fighters Will Help, but Kyiv Really Wants F-16s
description: Ukrainian officials and military analysts do not expect the MIG jets pledged so far by Poland and Slovakia to fundamentally alter the battle in the skies.

title: Protests Resume in France After Macron Pushes Through Pension Bill
description: After President Emmanuel Macron pushed his unpopular pension bill through Parliament without a vote, demonstrations about the changes broke out again.

title: Submarine Deal With U.S. and U.K. Sparks Debate in Australia
description: The agreement has raised concerns about the need for the costly plan and whether it could tether Australia to the United States.

title: Search Intensifies for Radioactive Canister Missing for Weeks in Thailand
description: It’s not clear exactly when the 55-pound cylinder containing cesium-137 vanished from the power plant where it was in use.

title: China’s Leader Sets State Visit to Russia
description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, is expected to hold talks with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia next week in a meeting that could have broad implications for the war. Here’s what we are covering:

title: Going Hungry in America
description: The country’s neediest are dealing with food stamp cuts and rising prices at the same time.

title: Japan-Korea Relations Improve, but Ties Are Still Fragile
description: Both sides face potential political snags, as well as a delicate balancing act in a region where the United States and China are competing for influence.

title: Slovakia Follows Poland in Pledging to Send Jets to Ukraine
description: The news came after Poland’s president that his country would send MIG-29 jets, a move that appeared intended to open the door to more advanced warplanes from NATO allies.

title: Xi, Cast as Peacemaker, Wades Into Russia’s War in Ukraine
description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, is expected to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia this month and speak with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine.

title: In Myanmar, Atrocities Rise as Army Comes Under Pressure
description: The rebellion against military rule is gaining strength, and analysts say soldiers are responding with increased brutality.

title: Israel’s Judicial Overhaul Protests Often Begin on Apps
description: A movement against the government’s judicial overhaul plan is a grass-roots affair spread by word of mouth and WhatsApp messaging groups.

title: Jailed in Egypt at 17, He Wrote to Survive and to Share His Long Ordeal
description: Sentenced as a teenager to 15 years for “unlawful assembly,” Abdelrahman ElGendy started recording the abuses of prison life. The idea of someday publishing his memoir gave him a reason to live.

title: As Dreams of Peace Wither, Nightmares Flourish in Ukraine’s Sleep
description: A survey asked hundreds of wartime Ukrainians what they dreamed about. Many replied: the war.

title: Banned From Russian Airspace, U.S. Airlines Look to Restrict Competitors
description: Because of the war in Ukraine, U.S. carriers have to take the long way on flights to and from Asia, giving an advantage to foreign rivals flying the same routes.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Private-sector bailout for First Republic Bank.
